name: Iloperidone (Fanapt)
summary: An atypical antipsychotic used in the treatment of schizophrenia.
description: Iloperidone is a second-generation (atypical) antipsychotic that works primarily through antagonism of dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors, along with effects on adrenergic receptors. It is approved for the treatment of schizophrenia in adults. Due to its alpha-adrenergic blocking properties, it is associated with a risk of orthostatic hypotension, especially during initial titration.

contraindications: Known hypersensitivity to iloperidone or formulation components
monitoring_required: ECG in patients at risk of QT prolongation

sections.text: Blocks dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors; also antagonizes alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, contributing to orthostatic hypotension.

adult.titrate: Increase gradually over 4–7 days to target dose

sections.geriatric: Use with caution; start at lower end of dosing range
sections.hepatic_impairment: Not recommended in severe hepatic impairment
sections.renal_impairment: No dose adjustment in mild/moderate impairment

items: Tablets: 1 mg, 2 mg, 4 mg, 6 mg, 8 mg, 10 mg, 12 mg

sections.text: Antipsychotic effects may be observed within 1–2 weeks, with full response potentially taking several weeks.

sections.black_box: Elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotics are at increased risk of death.
other: Titrate slowly to reduce risk of orthostatic hypotension

items: ECG in patients at risk of QT prolongation

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data
sections.lactation: Unknown excretion in human milk; use caution
sections.geriatrics: Greater risk of orthostatic hypotension; dose cautiously

sections.text: If discontinuing, reduce gradually over 1–2 weeks to minimize withdrawal and relapse risk.

items: Requires slow titration to target dose to minimize hypotension
Not considered first-line due to titration complexity and QT risk
May be an option in patients who fail other atypical antipsychotics
